Deer that I should think from their jumping were black tailed deer  we started them out of almost every thicket of bushes, this valley was quite large & pretty & I think must have been one the "Parks" so called by the trappers, we did not kill any deer here I did not even shoot at them, but watched their bounding in every direction = Every few rods = giving a bound much higher than the others,, camped at night on a small spring brook of clean cold water - rained some in the night  = morning cold enough for an overcoat & foggy = July 12th the other company following, refusing to pay any share of the guides expenses,, we after starting in the morning by a short turn, threw them off our track & it cost them considerable time & trouble to find our trail again. we passed over a level valley & forded a large stream Larimie Fork & nooned on the west bank, in the afternoon we travelled over a high stony plain, in some places making very hard travelling for our animals about like travelling over stone heaps, saw some hollows? where water & collected & evaporated white with Alkali some of the boys used it in cooking - without any material advantage I should judge, weather uncomfortably cold & we came shivering into camp = on guard from 12 to 2 = 13th started early = came across a stray buffalo bull. I chased him up a ravine & had him trapped as the walls were so steep he could not get out only by charging past me or over me. I shot 3 balls as near his heart as I could guess, which he took without flinching = but lowered his head & faced me torn page shaggy? hair standing Erect, & his Eyes looking like torn page of fire, as I was only some 3 or 4 rods distant

I expected he would charge at me as I fired, soon the other boys came up as they heard me firing & fired some 15 or 20 balls more before he sank upon his knees & then yeilded to his fate. we took what meat we could = found some pretty flowers = while we were behind killing our buffalo the guide came across a grizzly bear cub the Old bear was away & the guide had time to kill it & get it on his horse, when the old bear hearing, or winding? the intruder, returned & enraged at the loss of her cub, charged furiously on the guide,, he succeeded however in dodging here & escaping with the cub. I had a taste of the same at our nights encampment The meat was very good, but rather oily, camped on a small stream of good water = my mule having heavier packs than the others I distributed some of my loading, I have one little bay mule which I call santa fe = & a large brown mule both old mules = 14th travelled over a more broken country today & the ground covered with stones ^ 2 to 8 inches diameter fragments of rocks so as to make the travelling very difficult = stopped to noon in a small hollow at the foot of a high range of hills to the north & near a small grove of trees. we found here remains of an Indian camp. as we rode up we saw a herd of Elk (25 or 30) feeding & rolling in the dirt. Capt Stewart at about 20 rods distance fired at them & missed hitting none of them. they ran up the mountain near us, after we camped a single Elk made us a visit no doubt thinking our mules were related in some way to him - I crept towards him & kneeled in & succeeded in torn page - itting behind some bushes about 40 rods distant but as I aimed torn page a mule fed in front of my rifle & before it was out torn page range, one of the boys Mr Miller who had crept up torn page direction fired at him, I heard the ball strike the torn page

yet it stood perfectly still for a few moments, then ran a few rods & fell the ball went through the heart, it proved to be a young buck Elk, with horns some 6 or 8 inches & would probably weigh some 350 to 400 lbs did not move this afternoon & we jerked the meat of the Elk & boiled the tongue = in the afternoon an Elk doe came near our mules in the same way as the first, I elevated my sights for 300 yards (as I judged the distance) took deliberate aim behind the shoulders & fired at the same instant with 2 other boys, I was perfectly sure of my game but strange to say none hit her we threw in loose balls and as she still stood looking at us fired again, our loose balls probably did not hit her, & she got off, I loaded again to teel? my gun, & fired the same distance at a white spot, in a Cottonwood tree, I found my ball had ^ struck 1 foot above the spot, (exactly over) I then paced the distance & found it 200 yds instead of 300 & my ball had probably passed just over the Elks back, my sights being Elevated too much; it was not the fault of the fun, or aiming, but an error in guessing at the distance  15th Sunday travelled over a rough country between two mountains, Some of the boys climbed the north mountain the afternoon of Saturday & built up a fire on the summit & brought down some snow & as I had some citric acid we made some lemonade with snow added, Saw some antelope Mr Kinney shot one we jerked the meat, as our guide said game would soon be scarce, shot at an antelope about 40 Rods & overshot, saw a few wild geese & ducks & camp torn page the Platte river (which we found here too deep torn page torn page 3 Oclock, 16 Building rafts, had them torn page

finished when our guide who had been looking farther down the river came in with news that he had found a ford where he thought we could cross, we started for it & crossed, Capt Tuttle? lost one mule by drowning , we all got wet more or less, the weather quite cold & it soon commenced raining & continued until in the night we camped near a small stream near which grew many clumps of Willows I selected a dry clump & set fire to it & succeeded in rearming myself & drying my blankets a little, we made up our bed in the rain  on the wet grass, but we slept sound, nevertheless 17  dried our wet clothes & left camp early & travelled fast, as we are getting short of provisions are in hopes of getting some ^ provisions of the Mormons,, Country rolling, crossed snow in spots 3 or 4 feet deep - snow balled = & had some to eat - soon after passed over a low ridge & came to a little creek that ran to the South West the first water found that Empties into the Western Ocean, the ascent had been so gradual we knew not we were on the Western slope of the mountains, we stopped to noon about one Oclock on a branch of snake river, we found some difficulty in following the stream the banks were near the stream & very steep, killed one or two sage hens, about the size of common hen of a ^ brownish greyish mottled color = some like a hawk = flesh rather dark colored, but good, camped near some low bushes on the creek bottom grass good, night very cold with a heavy unclear 18th Wednesday travelled down the creek in the forenoon, had very hard travelling sometimes climbing the steep bluffs sometimes fording the rapid stream as it wound through the narrow valley, saw considerable torn page (Cottonwood) some dead from fire running through it,  nooned under some cottonwood trees, in the afternoon stri - torn page

over the ridges towards the southwest, saw fresh Indian trails & could tell  by the fresh horse manure that they had passed but a short time previous,, struck sake river = saw a few Antelope = but very wild = camped in a natural meadow of Wild Oats or rye or grass resembling the same as high as our mules backs & fine & thick at the bottom, it was the best feed seen, but I dreaded camping in so good a place for Indians to surprise us, we however increased our guard for the benefit of our animals, saw for the first time immense numbers of the large black cricket = water muddy as we descend the river = bottom sandy like the Arkansas - 19th Crossed the river to the S=E= side. the guide said near here he was caught in a snow storm he had been to a trading post after sugar etc & was alone. he made himself a sage brush hut to protect him from the storm, & hoppled his animals but they wandered off in the storm, he looked a number of days for his animals& then gave them up as lost & started for the nearest post ^ (fort Bridger) with what he could carry in hopes of reaching it on foot, & while travelling came unexpectedly on ^ the trail his lost animals, he had lived several ^ (7 or 8) days on sugar along, & his joy can be imagined, he showed us where he found the stray animals & still hoppled, saw several antelope one was killed = where we nooned today; one of the boys killed a monstrous Rattlesnake, day very warm travelled 'till 9 Oclock before finding grass to camp upon  - on guard from 2 'till 4 Oclock  = aroused the camp at 1/2 past torn page baked bread made some very good; Mr S Jackson taken torn page in the night, camp moved 8 or 9 miles, when

we had to wait for the litter to come up with the sick, shot a sage hen & = caught a young Rabbit & let it go again = camped in good grass = rained some in the night; & quite hard as we were packing in the morning, of 21st travelled fast = proved to be a rainy day = road in many places very difficult through ravines & up & down very steep hills in several cases the packs slipped entirely off ^ our mules & rolled down the steep hills, & we had to lead our mules down,, repack & climb up again, = travelled about 15 or 16 miles and camped about 10, the litter did not reach camp until 3 or 4, the sick man had to leave the litter & ride on a saddle over the steeped places, caught here a kind of fish resembling a lake herring, 22nd started early struck across the ridge, towards "Browns hole" on green river the snake river here enters a canyon & we left it & travelled over a very broken country,, over rocky ridges as steep as the mules could climb & then actually sliding in many places down the opposite side then again crossing deep ravines cut out of the sand from 5 to 100 ft deep on the ridges we passed clumps ^ of cedars 15 or 20 ft high & some ^ were 2 ft diameter at the base the wild sage bushes interfered very much with our travelling we were obliged to force our way through them, the country here looks as if swept with a flood perhaps some stream has been damed up & cut a passage through the country more rocky than we have before seen, in many places the rocks overhanging our road 100 or more ft high, did not find a place for nooning & pushed on as fast as possible towards green river, we saw it in the distance and towards sundown struck it just above where it enters a rocky (Kenyon or Cannon)

the mountains of red sandstone looks as though parted by some convulsion of nature for the river to pass through between perpendicular walls of rock 500 or more ft high, we camped on a little flat with a strip of good grass = sufficient for our tired & hungry animals, we travelled over 12 hours without food or water for our mules & must have travelled over 30 miles, some of the party Dr White & two or three others staid in camp refusing to travel sunday some horses gave our & were left behind & some among themMr Phillips did not reach camp till next day & as his mules carried our kitchen furniture. I eat crackers or hard bread soaked soft & bacon fried on a stick, we had a thunder shower towards evening ^ & wet blankets  Water of the river muddy & sandy on guard from 8 to 10 & from 4 to 6 in the morning 23rd moved camp a few miles up the river where we found some small cottonwoods that were dry having been cut down by the guide two or three winters ago for the purpose of housing his mules. we built two rafts to carry out packs = saddles = guns etc  across the river which is here some two to 300 yds wide & quite deep, after each trip we were obliged to tow our raft up the river to the starting point as it floated down a considerable distance at each crossing the mountain on the opposite side of the river is almost or quite a perpendicular ledge of rocks 1/2 to 3/4 of a mile high & more deserves the name of rocky mountain than any we have yet seen = shot a sage chicken = some of our party caught here fish resembling in shape a mackerel, but in color a lake herring  they would weigh from 1/2 to 2 lbs = Mosquitoes very troublesome, came in swarms I was obliged to put on my mosquito net = & gloves to protect my hands, some of the men unwell = Headaches & chills =

all crossed the river before dark, except the guard left with the mules 24th in the morning drove the mules in the river & swam them across as they came out we caught them with lariats = we saw smoke on the mountain. there are parties of Indians around us, that are telegraphing to other parties farther off,, We? have to keep on our guard & prepared for them all the time, bathed in the river one of our party came to my fire for coals & carefully dropped some in the dry grass near, before it could be subdued it burnt up my rubber coat & towels etc. on guard from 2 to 4 night cold 26th breakfast as soon as daylight = after we were packed up = just as I was starting = heard the report of a gun a short distance off & almost immediately a call for a doctor, I rode back & found a man^ from New Orleans belonging to a another party,, lying on the ground with his left arm shattered by a charge of buck shot = the charge going in at the wrist & lodging in the elbow, tearing the muscles & bones of the fore arm to peices, I took off my neck handkercheif (put a compress over the brachial artery) & twisted it until the bleeding stopped,, I told the man his arm would have to be taken off above the injury, but as we had no tools except a tenaculum & surgeons needle (in a pocket case) I had to make tools for the occasion out of such as could be had, I borrowed a dirk knife from one of our men & sharpened it on a flat smooth stone, until it would cut a hair. also found a carpenters saw & filed & set it, used old shirt for a sponge, & as we had no adhesive plaster was obliged to use stitches & bandages to keep tips of cut together = my neck-handkercheif answered very well

as a "Tournequet" Dr White = Morse = Briggs = & myself each took part in the operation Dr Morse used the knife Dr Briggs the saw & I took up the arteries & ligated them = after the operation (which the man bore very patiently) Dr White & one of his own party staid with him to help him along, & the rest of us Dr Morse Briggs & myself = hunted up the trail of our party & followed on as fast as we could = (as they had not waited for us) & were now several hours in advance. my guns were with my pack mules except my pistols = Dr Morse had rifle unloaded & no ammunition = which was all the arms we had with us = & what if we should lose the trail? which led up & along the sides of the mountain = over rocks & under overhanging rocks = seemingly ^ through the worst place we had yet encountered, we passed some cedar groves & groves of a kind of tree resembling at a little distance a peach or plum orchard = We had been without food since daylight & I was without a coat & a the sun sank in the west, we began to think we should have to camp supperless & alone = but as we reached the top of a high ridge we saw a smoke in a distant valley & hurrying on with better spirits we reached camp before nightfall = one of our men Mr Ellis had unpacked my mule the water here was in puddles or pools & poor = 26th started early - travelled fast = over hills & through valleys between the mountains = the mountain wooded with some pine & cedar = nooned on a small spring brook with wild sage fuel = travelled fast in the afternoon, & here the guide travelled into a rocky trap something in the shape of a horse shoe = we travelled around two or three miles to find a passage down the perpendicular wall of rocks &

after travelling the whole distance round on top of the wall, came round again to near the place where we Entered it, & perhaps is was well for a couple of Missourians who were following us, that we did, they had stopped to fix a pack that had turned when there suddenly appeared 9 Ute Indians = they caught their guns = when the indians stopped & made sign of peace. they had posted one of the indians as sentinel on the ridge & as we came in sight = ^ (the indians) hurried away in an opposite direction = stopped on a small stream of clear cold water in a small valley = 27th started down the mountain towards a distant valley, the guide today wounded a mountain sheep, my horse slipping upon the edge of a ledge of rocks nearly went over ^ a precipice = , road very rough as usual went over some sand hills & through gulleys. we passed one stream with good grass travelled fast & towards night camped in Ashley's creek = the grass for our animals poor = on guard from 12 to 2 water clear & cold = some nice trout 3/4 lb weight were caught here,, bathed in the creek = our mules look poor & faded & some are giving out daily our provisions also getting low, = we hope to procure some of the mormons 28th started early = travelled fast = without stopping at noon = towards night crossed a small stream & soon came upon more the "Uinta" river there were two streams with a strip of good land & grass between = saw an old log house or fort of some trappers who had once made a home here = in crossing a small stream my horse mired & fell down, many of the mules were mired  Mr Phillips had a mule give out today & came in late without it. I gave him some supper & then he returned for his mule & did not get back to camp until morning = poor grass = vomited & was sick in the night = caused probably by eating our jerked meat = the night was quite cold = and altogether rather unpleasant

29th started about 7  travelled till noon,, poor grass & little at that,, crossed in the afternoon a mountain the snow clad peaks of others were ^ seen upon our right = camped on a small stream at the foot of the mountain with good grass = night very cold = 30th packed very early & my mule broke the stock off my double barrelled gun rendering it useless = I had it upon my mule & she caught it under the pack of another mule & wheeling round = snapped the stock off close to the barrells = travelled 10 or 12 miles & nooned on "Lake River" poor grass = crossed the river it was very rapid & washed our mules down stream & made the other bank below,  in the bed of the stream were large stones & several of our mules fell down in crossing = travelled over a mountain = passed through a valley beyond - without water = the ground covered particularly on the hill sides with large rocks & stones which made the travelling unsafe & difficult = there were also cedars upon the ridges & our packs mules would often bring their packs in contact with the limbs & limbs ^ then or pack would have to give way = climbed up a mountain & came to a precipice on the opposite side which turned us back = we took a different course & tried again, we did not succeed in finding a place where we could descend to the valley, which we could see below us = where we knew we could find water = for ourselves & animals, having had none since our early noon camp  & the day being very warm we did not give up, & camp until after dark, I tried to eat some hard bread but without water after a few attempts I gave it up = the mosquitoes also added their mite in trying to dry us up = to avoid them I thought I would spread my blanket on ^ top of a large rock near by = I clambered upon it = & as it looked

suspiciously dark on the opposite side, I threw over a fragment of rock. & I could hear it strike against the sides of the rocks ^ very far below me = ^ it was the edge of a precipice hundreds of feet down thinking it might be a trifle dangerous if I should happen to fall out of bed. I concluded to accept a humble station = on guard from 2 to 4 = while on guard some of the men came in with some water = they had succeeded in finding a place where they could descend = we each had a small allowance = in the morning 31st started as soon as we could see & took the narrow path made or travelled by indians or wild animals, that led down the rocks which our desperate men had found in the night before & after about three miles travel camped on the river or stream below "Du-chesne" river = stopped an hour or so for water & breakfast = then struck down the river over sand hills = rocks = & through cedars = I walked most of the time = and drove my horse before me & led my pack mules = my horse is getting very weak in clambering up one steep rocky mountain side where the rocky path was almost cut out like stairs = he slipped & almost tumbled over backwards upon me. I placed my hands behind him, & pushed him as he seemed about balanced, he regained his balance however or he might have gone & taken me with him down the side of the mountain,, passed 2 or three springs (in a hollow) of cold water, camped sun an hour high on a rapid stream "Stony Creek" heard that the wounded man was well & coming up - Capt Bass's Company do not seem willing to pay part of the guide expenses, although travelling with us = 1st started sun 2 hours high travelled between the mountains up the left branch of the creek over a very rough road = worse if anything than common = camped on the left branch of stony creek = grass good = trout were caught = weighing perhaps 3/4 of a pound the trout here have black spots & red fins somewhat different from trout of the atlantic states = 2nd started early to cross the

mountain - the ascent was gradual on the left (or south) the land descended gradually = (on the north we travelled near the edge of a precipice) our road going up along its edge = until the pine trees in the valley hundreds of feet below looked like small bushes & nestling among the trees was a small lake, a perfect gem, its deep dark waters = reflecting the sky & mountains surrounding it,, We still kept ascending until we came upon snow & just by the edge of the snow the greatest variety of flowers yet seen,, it was ^ here all spring at once = & side by side were strawberries = Geraniums = different varieties of Larkspur = balm = roses = sunflower = wild Pea = Wild Flax = with many plants I never saw before = the mountain side where not wooded was almost a perfect flower garden = the most beautiful sight I ever saw,, ^ occasionally the path leading among and under dark forests of Fir - Cottonwood - Pines etc = & again through an open spot filled with flowers of every hue, & from our height - we could see far in the distance = green valleys = rocky steeps = & snow clad mountains = I shall never forget this beautiful wild place among the mountains, we found a little ^ stream made by the melting snows = with good grass = in the little valley at noon = in the afternoon we descended the stream = & down the mountain side = we had a new experience in road making = jumping fallen trees = forcing our way through thickets = in some places we had to cut our road through = once I jumped my horse over a log & found myself in a log pen & was obliged to jump out where I went in, where we could we followed down the bed of the stream, but this was obstructed by rocks & fallen trees, & night came on, & we unable to extricate ourselves from our dilemma, so we tied our animals to the trees, & made

the best of our situation, my clothes were torn in todays struggle, but worse than all I lost from my pocket my collection of pressed flowers. this I know I could not replace again = but on the morrow I commenced a new collection to replace them as far as possible = the search would probably have been unavailing but I was almost tempted to go back on foot, & search for them. ^ water froze in night. 3rd started as soon as we could see, without breakfasting, travelled four or five miles where we found grass for our animals = stopped a couple of hours for our animals to graze & cooked our breakfast & then started again on our journey sometimes along the side of the mountain if we could find a foot hold for our horses & sometimes in the river bottom, my ^ forward mule in crossing a small stream mired & went down in the mud & water,, I jumped in took off my telescope rifle & unpacked & helped him out & after going a few rods farther crossed another stream similar to the last my horse struggled through = my front mule mired & went down again, & the second mule undertook to jump over him, but unfortunately miscalculated & fell upon the back of the first mule pressing him nearly out of sight. I drew my hunting knife jumped in & cut my mules loose & drew the top around off the other & got him out then unpacked the other & helped him out, came near losing my watch the chain having broken. & my packs & provisions were soaked in the mud & water, & I was late at night drying my wet provisions etc by our camp fire = the river bottom grows wider as we go down & other streams make in - the soil here is also good in comparison with the sand hills & wild sage deserts we have heretofore passed = around us are snow covered mountains on every side, camped near a little creek emptying into the main stream - water froze tonight in our basins - the thickness of window glass = grass good  = 4th started early, travellled as usual along the mountain sides & down the valley until

about 3 Oclock when we camped for the rest of the day to give our tired & hungry animals a little better fare, we having sent on a committee to procure food of the mormons in advance of our party, they will travel all night if the moon gives sufficient light, our provisions are almost out, & we have supplied the other parties to keep them from starving, as their main articles have given out, on guard from 10 to 12 = 5th started early travelled along the side of the mountain, the river suns in a sort of Kenyon = which drove us above the rocky walls, sometimes on ledges hundreds of feet above the bottom of the valley = we could look back occasionally & see our train scattered along the mountain ^ side, each picking his way as best he could. we picked here a few service berry's, they are some larger than a Whortleberry resembling it somewhat = black = & of a sweetish taste = growing on a bush several feet high something like a thorn bush = also saw snow berry bushes had seen them also between the Platte & Green rivers = also saw wild Currants = about three oclock we came into a ^ narrow gorge or pass with rugged mountains on either hand, towering far above us = into the clouds & the region of perpetual winter = we could see far away above us, the snow fields cold & white upon the peaks above us, then occasionaly a grassy spot upon the mountain side below, & then lower still = but hundreds of feet above us yet,, two or three streams made by the melting snows = leaped over its perpendicular rocky sides & dissolved long before reaching the bottom into mist & spray, & far above our heads wherever possible many a bush & tree "cast anchor in the rifted rock," & higher yet the Pine tree hung = His shattered trunk & frequent flung - Where seemed the cliffs to meet on high = Its boughs athwart the narrowed sky,, Highest of all where white peaks glanced - Where glistening streams waved & danced - The wanderer's eye could barely view - The summer heavens delicious blue; So woundrous wild the whole might seem - the scenery of a fairy dream = yes we were dreaming = & enjoying the wondrously wild sight, when we found ourselves face to face = upon the rocky shelf = where we were travelling, with a band of Eutaw indians,, they found a place wider than

our path & went into it to allow us to pass, as I rode opposite to them one of the indians, pretending to throw the blanket over his shoulders (in doing so) frited? it in my horses face, making him shy almost over the edge of the precipice, I turned my horse towards him & spoke very sharply = & he went off from the track, = they had a number of good horses = the women carried their Papooses lashed to straight peices of wood = with willow twigs bent over the childs head so as to form a roof or shade = several ^ Indians followed us some distance = one fired off his gun & called out to some others of his party across the ravine "Sacre God-dam = Americanos = shoot" = soon after as we journeyed on = upon going round a point of the mountain = we saw to the southwest the Eutaw lake spread out in the valley before us, it reminded me of our own Owaseu? but how far distant = Way worn & weary  = almost out of provisions = & the worst part of the journey yet before us = one mule gave out today = after emerging into the Eutau valley we turned to the north & after travelling 5 or 6 miles camped near two small runs on the east side of the valley = wild sage for wood = 6th Packed my mules Mr Mead took charge of them, & Col Whiting & myself concluded to visit the lake & fish in its waters. we rode 4 miles to the lake, we found nothing on its shores to make a raft = so we caught some grasshoppers stripped = waded out to our necks in the water & fished  we caught several fish resembling lake herring & about the size = killed a snipe = a young ^ woman came up on horseback. Said they were beginning to harvest & that we could probably get a supply of provisions = that thousands of migrants had passed through, & were leaving their waggons & buying Pack mules. he asked if the Eutau Indians had troubled us - said they (the mormons) killed 4 near here last winter for stealing, = said there was plenty of fish in the lake & in the streams very nice trout,, that sometimes the suckers were so plenty they tied hooks on to poles & hooked them out = we cooked some of our fish  = and about 3 Oclock started back on the trail of the company = the sun was very hot = we travelled 8 or 9 miles & then stopped to let our horses

graze & get some supper. we had put our fish in an india Rubber stocking & we found them spoiled or cooked by the hot sun as if they had been boiled = after supper started we travelled until about 10 oclock = evening warm = turned off the trail up a dark ravine = & camped for the night = woke up about midnight animals quiet = & then slept soundly until morning 7th Breakfasted on hard Bread Bacon & Tea soon after started upon riding over a ridge saw the salt lake in the distance & two or more rocky Islands. the air in the valley seems very clear, & the city could be very plainly seen seemingly near but in fact quite a number of miles distant. travelled fast & reached the camp of our company on the south of the city about 10 oclock,, some Mormons came into camp, treated us very friendly = & appeared very intelligent men, they will sell us flour at $10 pr 100 lbs wheat $3 45 pr Bushel milk pr qt 5c Bacon 10c clothing St Louis prices = horses $150,, mules $100 to $200 = shoeing mules $1 pr foot  = Guns & Waggons = of no value. Confirmed the stories of the California Mines = said there was gold near the Mormon settlements but they did not want it, & did not seek for it as they had plenty to live on & id not need gold as much as other things = they have  = grist mills = saw mills, & lumber $3 pr 100 ft & a press soon to be in operation. Horses, Cattle, Sheeps, Hogs, Hens, & good fields of wheat = corn & all sorts of garden vegetables = they however depend on irrigation they have ditches into which they turn the mountain streams that come from the East & the ground thouroughly watered as often as the plant or crops require it. Dr Briggs = Mr Philips = & 4 or 5 others with myself took Dinner at Bishop Crosbys we had roast beef = boiled pork = Biscuit & butter = green peas = Green beans = cucumbers = onions = butter milk = etc etc we did ample justice to the different articles = & some of our party seemed to think the mormons could set as good a table as we could = after dinner took a stroll in the Bishops garden saw very nice Rutabagas = Tomatoes = Melons - Corn - Peas -  Beans etc = The mormons think they have been hard used = their laws are very strict = a Theif they make restore 4 fold the amount stolen, besides a fine which goes to the society & also give him up to the owner of the property stolen to be dealt with as he thinks best - they have a Council

of 50 men to make laws = they claim now 12000 Inhabitants in the valley = they say Emigrants by the south pass route have suffered severely = grass all fed off = cattle dying & that there are a thousand graves along the Platte of those who have died of cholera. We think of crossing the desert south of the Salt Lake = but they discourage us & say it is impossible & that we will all perish if we undertake that route that there are hidden Saleraties?, salt beds where our animals will break in & be lost & long stretches without grass or water = the northern route ^ 800? miles through is destitute of grass = there is a route south (1100 miles) = but we must wait 6 weeks for the fall rains = after a consultation (the company having dissolved = ) Dr White = Mr Force = Capt Tuttle = S Jackson = Mr Horn = Mr Sewell = Mr Philips = Capt Smith = Mr Goodrich = Mr Corning = Mr Howell = Close = Olney = Nichols = & myself making 15 men = came to the determination to take the desert route = we fortunately found at this juncture a "Mr Craig" a very estimable gentleman = who told us we had succeeded once in crossing the desert & thought he could do so again = we gave him $25 ,, find his provisions & carry 38 lbs of clothing for his services = Sunday august 19th in the afternoon went into the city = which covers a large extent of territory = the villiage lots are all large lots  the houses many of Adobes = we found a place to camp in one of the city lots = & slept therein by the side of our mules 'till morning. in the morning 20th we saw one of our party & went to their encampment & completed our arrangements, bought some wheat had it ground = saving the coarse feed for our mules on the desert, bought a little sorrel mule of Geo Hale = had our mules shod I had now three mules (as the company had taken my horse Pau Pau? & sold it) & I had taken a pack mule in its place a black mare mule 4 years old = our previous guide Mr Kinney selected this animal for me & I found her a very hardy & serviceable animal I had also one of my old pack mules = an old brown ^ Santa Fe mule, & a very good animal = we take only 80 lbs to a mule & throw away all articles not absolutely necessary = we left the city this evening & camped ear some brackish pools of water = & about one oclock

at night = made 15 or 18 miles = 21st travellled about 2 miles & overtook & passed small party going with us, & as we neared the lake we turned down upon a rocky point to bathe = the water of the lake is of a beautiful blue (in the distance) & very transparent = the shores are encrusted with sale = & the water a saturated solution = strong as any brine = we could float upon the water, without any exertion with about 1/3 of the body above the surface when we came out our hair & bodies were soon crusted with salt & as we rode on in the hot sun we did not feel as comfortable as we wished later in the day my sorrel mule started away from the train with its head up snuffing I tried to head it but it ran around me & toward a distant hollow I followed on to overtake it, it went down into the hollow to a pool of water but instead of drinking stood looking at it as if in disgust, bring very dry I dismounted & tasted of the water & then I could appreciate the mules feelings, she willingly retraced her steps & joined the train - the water was quite salt & nauseous. we travelled around a point of the mountain south of the lake & then towards the south on the western side, & found a small stream of pure water = upon which we camped = with good grass = as soon as possible after camping we took a bath & rinsed off some of the salt = made about 25 miles = 22nd started early travelled around the north point of the second ridge then south again on its western side stopped an hour or so near some springs of brackish water about 21 miles from our last camp. then travelled nine miles to some deep springs or holes of good water called "hope wells" this is our last good water & grass this side of the desert = we found here a company of a few waggons & cattle encamped preparing & resting for the desert. 23 cut grass = made hay = & tied it up in bundles, to pack for our animals = in a tight Rubber bag, I put 6 buckets of water = also packed = = 15 lbs middlings = & 13 lbs hay & my rifle on my riding saddle we started on the desert early on the morning of the 24th Aug = with the intention of walking as far as we each could & thus

spare our animals as much as possible. late in the forenoon we reached some springs of brackish ^ sulpherous water "Dell Springs" in a small ravine to the left of the trail, near the foot of a ridge of mountains,, there was a little scanty? grass and we stopped here a short time to rest to dine = my feet are getting sore in consequence of wearing moccasins which I supposed would be best for their lightness = after resting we crossed the ridge & started on our way across the desert intending to travel all night & until we reached the opposite side = only stopping as our animals needed rest = a few hours now will decide whether we can cross the desert or not = we have tried to provide for every emergency = Mr Philips & myself footed it in company we travelled until the moon went down or until about midnight = my feet were swollen & sore & I had begun to complain first = but Mr Philips now gave in & declared he could walk no father = so we stopped fed our animals & while they were eating - lay down on the ground to rest = after stopping about an hour we watered our animals shifted our packs so we could ride = & pushed on, about daylight we came up with the main party who had stopped to rest under the shelter of some drifting sand knolls = the wind fortunately was in the north & cold = disagreeable = but favourable for our animals = preventing thirst = & fatigue we stopped here and fed & watered again = our road after crossing the first ridge has been tolerable level with an occasional slight ridge to crop & in many places the ground is encrusted with saline matter as thick as window glass and as our mules break through the noise made is like the breaking of Ice & in the darkness & cold we can easily fancy it is ice + it makes the travelling = somewhat more difficult as the ground is in many places soft, though dry as ashes in other places there are hard spots upon

which the mules hoofs make little impression = in many places the sand drifts like drifting snow = in some places there are a few clumps of wild sage & then again as far as the eye can reach not a shrub = or a blade of grass = or living thing = but ourselves can be seen upon the dreary waste = desolation weighs supreme = resumed our journey about sunrise = we had made about 36 miles we calculated & we travelled as fast as we could = we often saw Deceptive bodies of water in the distance or "Miriage" Mr Philips in one ^ place would not admit it was a delusion but was confident it was a lake = another seeing some magnified sage bushes & believing them animals going to drink remarked "now those animals will get to that lake & drink enough to kill themselves" our course was now north of west towards a distant point of mountains = after rounding the point = came up with the company of waggons that had started on the desert before us = a good many of their cattle had given out & were left on the desert to die & they had to abandon some of their waggons in consequence, it seemed hard to see animals thus left to perish = our course now was nearly west toward a distant ridge of mountain = we had travelled since sunrise without stopping, and as it grew dark some of our company who had reached the opposite side = built up a bright fire to guide us in,, I fell asleep several times & dropped my leading rope, we met waggons of the other company going back with water to succor their comrades left in the desert = they had left their loading & hurried on in advance = to return & succor them as soon as possible = our company did not all get in 'till morning One man Nichols walked all the way = I reached camp in the evening = saw Indian camp fired on the mountain above us = but we were all too tired to think of keeping guard even if our scalps were the forfeit = & I was too tired to cook any supper = but stretched myself upon the ground as soon as possible (after caring for my animals) & forgot all my troubles in sleep

we had here good grass & excellent water in deep holes or springs called "Bonarks? Wells" 26th sunday lay by to recruit our animals = had a sermon from a member of the other company (a Preacher) Mr Batchelor here came up with us he started from the Mormon City thursday morning = hurried on to overtake us = did not know when he reached the desert = & would perhaps have perished = as he had about given up hope = when he came in sight of the waggons = ^ he was in nearly a fainting condition they gave him water & after he had rested he came on = we did not lose an animal = on guard from 10 to 12 = 27 started about four oclock to travel again in the night as we have another stretch of 35 miles to water = our road was quite level = with some wild sage bushes, but no grass = the ground in places crusted with saline matter = we travelled 'till moondown & it was with great difficulty I could keep awake on my mule after stopping we tied our animals to sage bushes; & I having some shorts & a canteen of water - my mules had better fare than the others = after they were cared for I spread my blankets on the ground & slept very soundly 'till morning 28th about sunrise we were in the saddle again crossed the ridge of mountains before us travelling up a ravine & struck directly for an opposite ridge some 12 or 15 miles distant we reached our camp at "chiles cache" about 11 = we found water partly in pools & tolerable good = spent the day here = just about sundown the mules became frightened in some way & stampeded in a body = they swept around in a circle at full speed they would pass the camp = this was our only chance = what if we could not stop them? & ^ we should be left alone & on foot among the deserts wastes? the probabilities were that we would perish before we could extricate ourselves = these thoughts flashed through our mind & we all acted simultaneously we ran to stop them spreading over as much space as possible & succeeded in heading them off = we picketed most of our animals now to guard against a repetition of the stampede = Ice formed tonight in our basins quite

thick = one of our Party Mr Jackson had his boots stolen in the night by wolves = he found one again which they had dropped = his bridle & sircingle were torn in peices = & this without awakening him & his boots were so near he could put his hands on them = 29th started early about sunrise = soil some better. travelled south along a ridge of mountains = through sage bushes as usual = walked most of the way = 16 miles to "Warm Springs" stopped to noon in the afternoon travelled 12 or 16 miles to "Mound Springs" called so from springs on the top of 2 or 3 small mounds. a party travelling in company with us stopped at Warm Springs to rest their horses = in the night our mules started back to join them we succeeded in stopping all but 3 which delayed us half a day to recover them = 30th we occasionally see an antelope again caught sight of an Indian in the distance = & see numerous signal smokes on the mountains = there must be many bands of them Judging by the signs & smokes Our former Guide Mr Kinney said "if you meet any Snake Indians, shoot them at sight , they are not fit to live" we are now among them. in the afternoon crossed a ridge of mountains & valley as usual & travelled to "Mill Springs" all the water so far is found on the eastern side of the mountain ridges = there is a fine stream formed here by the spring = safe brush for food as usual Water froze solid in our basons tonight = 31st at the usual hour for saddling my mules had wandered (in feeding) up the valley beyond the others, I went after them without fire arms, (not wishing to be encumbered with them) when I had almost reached my animals = suddenly from behind a ridge (where they had been concealed) = two Indians appeared = one was armed with a gun = the other had a bow & arrows = unarmed I was at their disposal, as I thought = & kept on towards my mules = they followed & made signs of peace. the one with a gun made signs = that he was out of ammunition & wanted some to load his

gun = as I had none with me, they followed me to the camp in hoped of obtaining some = but as I told the boys not to give them any, they went away disappointed = I asked "Snake" & pointed towards them = they shook their heads with a deep "Ugh" of dissatisfaction & then said "shoshonee" shoshonee" = when we started we thought we would try & cross the mountain ridge in front of us (West) & save a long bend to the south (to go around) its we succeded in scaling its rocky side after two or three hours hard work = & found the opposite side much better & upon descending found ourselves in what we called the "valley of Fountains" certainly an agreeable name in the desert country. we here found a small stream on the west side of the ridge - & towards noon camped with good grass & wood in the valley, Capt Tuttle here got seperated us supposing he had taken another route or trail around the mountain = stopped here 2 hours then seeing a low place in the range west of us struck into that to the right & crossed it though the ground was very broken cut up with ravines, late in the afternoon we struck a trail where cattle had been travelling south, what did it mean we examined the tracks, they were hurried along, & on the trot, = without waggons = going away from any Emigrants route = we looked closer = bare feet tracks of savages behind them explained it all = Indians had plundered some emigrant train & driven the cattle off = as we deciphered the signs = we kept a good lookout = & were in hopes of falling in with some plundering band & teach them one of the commandments = we camped late at night on a stream running north a branch emptying into the Humbolt river = travelled about 25 miles = night cold on guard from 12 to 2 oclock in the morning,, our mules were some little distance from our camp  = (for better grass=) & I was alone = the mules were restless & started = snorted = & seemed afraid

of certain clumps of bushes near, I walked through the bushes in different directions = thinking they might conceal some lurking savages but discovered none = when my time expired I called two men for the morning guard = as was our custom = Mr Sewell & Capt Smith, after they came out = I had hardly wrapped my blankets around me for a nap before I heard a Gun & the cry "Hurra the Camp" being awake I caught my gun & was the first one out, I met Mr Sewell & asked "where?" he replied "to the four winds", I asked hoping to get some clue = "which way most of them had gone"? he pointed in the direction = & then asked "which way is camp?" he seemed bewildered. I told him "in the direction of the morning star", then calling to the boys in camp to saddle up one mule we had picketed near camp & start out as quick as possible. I ran as hard as I could in the direction taken by the mules = but I must confess with a faint of hope of overtaking them in the darkness & if we should lose them = what should we do? after travelling about a mile I heard Mr Smith some ways off on my left calling for help. I answered = went in his direction,, guided by his voice - he said he had "some of the mules penned up in a bend of the river" we kept them there until our men came up & then caught them = the stream had very fortunately for us stopped them in their stampede & we found them all together, our Joy can be imagined = what caused the stampede we could only conjecture = the probability was they were startled by some prowling savages - or animal = most likely the former = Sept 1st started early = travelled four or five miles to finding good grass & knowing the grass would be soon ahead of us

concluded we would stop here until Monday, & let our animals recruit? built me a house of willow boughs to shield from sun & rain = saw here a good many sage hens = ducks etc & some water snakes,, found a indian jug made of willow twigs coated with pitch to make it tight, Sunday 2nd in camp Monday 3rd started very early & struck the main emigrant after about 4 miles travel, saw from the clouds of dust where it was before we reached it = the many waggons & teams passing had pulverized the dry soil & the wind had blown it out of the track so that the road in some places was worn 2 feet deep in the earth = & the grass along the road ^ was gnawed down into the very ground by the starving animals, & this & the bushes were covered with a thick coating of dust,, travelled fast to hurry over the poor feed as fast as possible crossed the river to noon = poor feed = travelled about 30 miles & crossed the river again in hopes of finding better feed = but was disappointed = on guard from 2 1/2 to 5 oclock = Sept 4th started early = passed many emigrants = Families = & single = Women on horseback & on foot as well as children = passed some Mormons on their homeward way from California they gave us encouraging news  = gold plenty = also provisions = they say the grass is poor ahead = & that most of the cattle must starve = we hundreds or thousands (would be better) have done already = we see dead animals = Horses & cattle = lying all day along the road = where they have given out & died & flocks of ravens upon & over them = it is a sickening sight = stopped a short time to noon & in the afternoon travelled over the mountains about 20 miles found Springs near the centre of the distance, but grass all eat off near them = camped late at night = twp of our company did not reach camp Mr Horn & Nichols = 5th started early = after travelling about 8 miles found tolerable grass & stopped to let our animals feed = after starting came across Mr Nichol = Mr Horn & Mr Baldwin & Howard = fellow voyageurs camped late & found fair feed as they valley here was quite wide

Mr Horn being unwell I took his guard hours from 7 till 9 1/2 oclock = I went out alone & without even a pistol & the mules some distance from our camp = when my time had nearly expired, I saw a dark object creeping towards me (or the animals) I thought it was an Indian at first, & regretted my being without arms = it came up within a rod or two of me when I saw that it was a large wolf = it had not discovered me = ^ as I had stood perfectly still = & as I sprang towards it = it jumped away = very much frightened at finding unexpected company , so near = Thurs? Sept 6 started early - travelled through sage bushes & dust as usual, passed ^ Govt trains with supplies ^ for Fort [Hall?]] going east as well as west = & some men with packs on their own backs = on foot = trudging on for life = their animals probably having given out = travelled about 15 miles & nooned on poor grass = day warm as usual = nights comfortable = Travelled in the afternoon 10 or 12 miles = passed some emigrants whose cattle had been stolen by the Indians = they tracked them to an Indian villiage * as they did not find the cattle took a horse away from one of the Indians when a large body of Indians appeared & fired on them = when they retreated = two of their men who had seperated were not seen afterwards = night before last some emigrants saw Indians prowling around like wolves dressed in their skins ^ camped on good grass = 7th last night some waggoners camped near us had three horses stolen by 5 Indians near morning they were discovered & the animals recovered = but the Indians escaped = one party we passed ^ today had lost cattle & one ox had over 20 arrows sticking in him = they were extracted, & the ox recovered = camped about sundown grass poor = one of our guard thought he saw Indians prowling around our camp = but as a good watch was kept = they did us no harm = Made this day 25 miles = 8th Sat started very early = our animals look poor = my mules backs are quite sore I walk as much as I can to save them,, as we pass emigrants we hear daily of Indian depredations = many

have lost animals = some wish to get up a party to recover cattle & fight the despoilers = they say there is a large villiage some 40 or 50 miles distant where they have large numbers of stolen animals = the trouble is almost all are in too great a hurry to get through = to stop on uncertainties heard ^ today of one Indian shot while prowling about an emigrant camp = & another frightened off = camped about 11 oclock & as we found here they valley very wide with good grass = we voted to stay here until Monday & let our animals recruit? = we have to let our animals fill themselves where they can find grass sufficient = came upon 13 of the Auburn boys here = Mr Fanning among them = also heard that the Missers? Hall were encamped a short distance above us = several of our company went up & made them a call = I staid in camp to take up some bread the Gurad thought there were Indians prowling around last night but did not see them distinctly enough in the darkness to make sure = Sunday 9th in Camp = baking bread & repairing saddles etc = saw turtle doves = Ducks & cranes etc an Ox mired near camp & 8 or 10 ^ of us with a rope drew him out, Monday Sept 10 started early = travelled over the same dry soil & through sage bushes & grease wood bushes as usual & past many dead animals = saw a man ahead of me with a telescopic rifle I thought the owner must be Mr Ketchell = (as I knew of no other such rifle ^ but his except my own upon the plains = ) & as I suspected he proved to be the owner he had found very little use for it the game being very scarce on the main route, passed many waggons = crossed the river & nooned grass poor made about 12 miles = in the afternoon travelled over some dry sandy ridges to cut off bends in the river our course now south west = we think we have passed the great northern bend of the river & Mr Craig thinks about 70 or 80 miles

from the sink the road here strikes off to the right on a 14 miles stretch to avoid or cut off a bend in the river = the grass here all eat off = the Auburn Co camped near us tonight = on guard from 9 1/2 to 12 night cold = we here found Capt Tuttle = Tuesday 11th morning cool = crossed a sandy ridge to avoid a bend in the river, sand deep & travelling difficult, with so much dust we could hardly see or breathe = our persons & clothes were covered = found at noon across the river a patch of good grass but somewhat dried which latter fact came near proving disastrous = one of our men carelessly dropped some fire in the grass & although he tried imediately to beat it out, it spread very rapidly = our packs were scattered here & there in the grass,, & our mules with the fire in their rear, were hemmed in by the river on two sides (as the mules were in a bend of the same) we saw the danger at a glance & we all fought desperately to put it out = the frightened animals gathered on the extreme point of land snorting in terror = at first the fire had the best of it = but our continued efforts & a strip of poorer grass enabeled us to conquer, in the afternoon travelled over a sandy plain passed the oregon road on the new road to "Feather River" emigrants had here placed many notices upon sticks, etc to notify friends in the rear of the road they had chosen & their destination etc = camped about sundown no grass scarcely = Wed 12th started run an hour high = course southwest on north west side of river & through a sage plain = saw Rabbits ^ black tailed, & sage hens also fox tracks in the dust, towards noon turned in towards the river and crossing sand hills found a small patch of grass in a hollow, that had not been found by emigrants before us - we stopped here about 3 hours & after starting & travelling some distance found I

had left my Rubber Cloth, returned for it & did not overtake our party again till nearly night = camped about sundown = grass eat off & poor = some of our men did not reach camp till very late & some stayed out all night = rained considerable from 8 to 10 oclock 13th started early travelled till about 1/2 past 12 when we camped on good grass 6 or 7 miles south ^ east of the road & 6 or 8 miles above the slough or sink = found quite a number of waggons encamped here = with straggling Digger Indians, that had come in to pick up cast off clothes & beg & steal all they could most of them were armed with guns = travelled yesterday about 23 miles by road & some 30 miles in our wanderings to find grass = today about 15 miles = most of our party stopped here = before entering the desert to let our animals recruit = but Dr White = Sewell = Olney & Close went on next morning so as not to travel the day after (Sunday) heard of grass near the sink & 14th went down 6 or 7 miles to be so much on our way we found here many dead animals & poor water in holes, burned grass to fry our bacon on guard from 9 1/2 to 12 = Capt Tuttle our morning guard went to sleep & our mules we found scattered = 15th started about sunrise travelled over a low level plain which looked like the bed of dried up lake to the sink = proper = which we reached about noon = found a few pools of stagnant water with many dead animals in & around them, the stench was intolerable = in some places the dead animals lay in heaps perhaps one or two hundred could be counted without moving your position = the emigrants had dug holes by the side of the pools to filter the water somewhat = & this all were obliged to use, fed our mules some hay we had cured at our last camp & then started on the desert = saw Miriages frequently to taunt us, after travelling a few miles the trail divides most of the emigrants going by the left hand route or Salmon River route we took

right hand route to Truckee River = we reached the hot or boiling Springs about 9 in the evening,, the guide had found them first & struck a fire to guide us in. we found here many boiling springs & numberless holes from which hot vapor issued & we were obliged to pick our way in the dark cautiously to avoid falling in them,, in places the ground sounded hollow, by stamping upon it = we made some coffee with the hot water furnished gratis = to disguise the taste of the water it tasted like a solution of Epsom salts very nauseous, we cooled some in tubs for our animals but few would drink it. found here many dead animals & one alive which we shot, he would otherwise perish by starvation = fed our remaining hay = rested till towards morning & then started again walking to rest our animals 2 of our mules gave out & were left on the desert = passed many dead cattle = abandoned waggons = clothing = Gun barrels = ox chains - yokes etc etc these told their own story of toil & suffering = the travelling very difficult most of the way through the sand = about 11 oclock Mr Craig in advance reached a high ridge & soon we saw his hat waving & heard his hurrah = we knew that meant deliverance - & we were not slow in answering his glad shout & from the top of the ridge we too soon ^ saw the line of cottonwood trees which told us where the truckee river had its course = the first trees we had seen since leaving the salt lake city = upon reaching the river our thirsty animals rushed full well into the river & would not stir until their thirst was slaked. caring not how much of a soaking our packs received in the meantime = my powder & caps I found rather

damp to say the least, as well as some of my clothing & we found poor feed where we struck the river but moved up the river a short distance & found better grass also Dr White & the rest of our party = we here had a meeting under the trees & after that laid down in the shade being very tired & fell asleep awoke chilly with headache & feeling quite unwell three of the men went back to bring up if possible the mules they had left upon the desert = the river here is some 40 or 50 feet wide & perhaps averaging at this season two to 4 ft deep or perhaps 5 ft but in most places fordable with a stoney bed & swift clear water, 17th heard from California by a gentleman returning to meet expected friends, that Provisions were procurable at reasonable prices all things considered & gold washing averaged perhaps an ounce daily per hand = we travelled up the river about 15 miles when we stopped to noon grass at intervals where the river valley widens out but most of the way the valley is narrow & we have to cross & recross the streams many times to to 20 times daily to find passage around the rocky stony sides of the valley = have been gradually feeling worse daily = with Dysentery use Blue pill & opium & rice water for food = moved up the river a mile or so to better grass & camped nights quite cold 18th Eat no breakfast felt scarcely able to pack my mules but finally accomplished it rode about 12 or 13 miles to where they valley is wide (some 6 or 8 miles) with good grass, some of our mules mired in crossing a slough, crossed the river many times crossing very bad on account of the many large stones in the bed of the stream but we have passed so

far without serious accidents, there are trout (Salmon) in the river two feet in length we were told by one of another company, he baited with small fish & fished where the stream ran rapidly, the hills are high though not very abrupt each side of the river in some places limestone appeared in other places the ^ red brick colored dirt we afterwards found in the "diggings" on the west side of the "Sierra Nevada" our road growing more rocky & rough as we proceed up the mountain,, camped at night about three miles higher up near the head of the valley  = felt very unwell & passed a very uncomfortable night = 19th grass good road rocky & rough quite sick so I can hardly keep my seat but obliged to travel camped at noon near some springs near where the road turns to the right = bought here a small blanket the nights now cold & frosty = we left the river here to the left & wound among the hills which are timbered with large pines = Red Wood which we afterwards saw & became better acquainted with, also spruce or Balsam trees, camped in a small valley with a little stream winding through it, we found here many waggons camped & some ladies chatting & singing = & children crying etc = I was right glad to get off my mule being scarcely able to keep my seat, I can eat scarcely anything & nothing but pure blood passes my bowels = the nights are cold & water tonight froze in our basons = I build up a fire near some large tree and as often as I get up stir up the fire & add thereto. the guard of the other company fired off guns during the night to intimidate any indians prowling around,, but it would seem of doubtful utility. but in the night the sound could be heard two miles & would as surely tell the savages where to find

us, 20th started sun about an hour high = morning cold = road torn page and rocky = passed some small creeks = camped about 1 or 2 oclock three or torn page miles from "Truckee Lake" eat only a spoonful or two of rice = stopped but a short time = soon after starting passed two cabins where the "Donner Family" were caught in the snow and perished they were among a dense forest of pine trees = in a ^ small valley = we saw stumps of trees which we judged 6 or 7 ft high = but none as high as in the written account soon after left the lake to the right & began to ascend the dividing ridge of the sierras road near the top (1/4 of a mile) very steep & rocky snow on the peaks around us. the waggons here double their teams in ascending & let their waggons down with ropes on the opposite side using pine trees as "snubbing" posts = many deeply cut with the ropes coiled around them = they then unyoked the cattle & drove them down narrow rocky paths to where they could be used again,, our men drove their mules & walked over the dangerous paths = but I could not do so,, it was all I could do to keep my seat & trust the rest to my mule who picked his way with great care where a single misstep would have been the last one. after descending entered the valley of ^ the Yuba rode down some three miles where we found a little grass and camped our animals very tired Dr Whites gave out but he succeeded in getting him in very late, we are now across the summit & on the tributaries of the Sacramento we have looked for gold but we have looked in the drifting sands of the streams & of course have not found it there. the metal is too heavy to be washed with the drift/ but is found in the hard dirt & stones or on the bed rock - 21st started late around 9 oclock only intending to travel about 8 miles as we would then have next day a longer distance before we could find grass for our animals

torn page -aig our guide & most of the party started ahead of us. my weak torn page -te making the work of packing & moving tedious Mr Philips assisted me on my mule , & I finally started, but after proceeding some distance the advanced party had turned off & I lost the trail & took another route, & in the meantime my little sorrel mule which I was driving before me, took the idea that she would go back to our camp to look for her lost companions. no argument I could advance had the least effect. I would plant myself in her way & try to drive her back - but she would jump fallen trees dogedly? around bushes & plunge through sloughs = & so we raced it through the woods until we were all exhausted/ Mr Philips fortunately appeared in sight & we both managed to capture her & by my leading her & the application of a whip, by Mr Philips, we prevailed over her obstinacy. we saw some little lakes to the left of us among the hills. the water looked dark as though they were deep & clear. our road worse if anything than usual up hill & down over rocks where emigrants had to let down their waggons with ropes, passed women & children on foot = travelled until night = & had about concluded we should have to camp in the forest without grass for our mules, when came to a small opening & found some emigrants encamped but without water = I had eat nothing since morning = & I was compelled to nibble a mouthful or two from a peice of dry hard bread, in the night Mr Philips came to me with some water he had procured = passed a very uncomfortable night the Dysentery still reducing my strength & in addition one of my knees was much swoolen & painful = 22nd in the morning Mr Craig rode into camp = saying he "had tired his mule nearly out to catch us, he said,, we had travel

thirty two miles, it took ox teams 4 or 5 days to accomplish the same distance we started late. saw many Pine = Red Wood & other evergreen trees = many ^ Pines 6 to 8 ft diameter & perhaps of nearly the same size = 60 ft to the first limbs & Red Wood trees nearly as large = the latter is a species of cedar = wood quite red = splits very straight = & makes excellent shingles = & lumber passed over a steep ridge = the descent ; dangerous - & difficult = especially for me compelled to ride = we entered the valley below & found an encampment & a mile or two farther on Mr Craig & others of our party. camped on the south side of the valley near the edge of timber. grass very poor our mules eat the dry oak leaves, and are tired & faded. my riding ^ animal a 4 yr old black mare mule, has carried me over the mountains where other mules have given out with scarcely any loading = I have many times pitied her, but my pity has seemingly been wasted & she rises superior to all hardships in desert or mountain = 23rd Sunday in camp = had a forenoon & afternoon meeting under some tall pines on the farther side of the valley & preaching & singing, with female voices joined in the last exercise it reminded me of home 24th started early = came up with a party who had killed two black tailed deer, bought? a little peice for soup, & with rice boiled in, seemed to give me renewed strength = it tasted delicious = passed pines 8 or 9 ft diameter = after a few miles kept on the ridge to the right of bear creek the rocks giving way to hills of yellow or reddish sand,, we saw encamped here & there of gold miners & men washing out gold with Rockers or Cradles = they say 1/2 an ounce daily is an average & that the prices of flour is 90c to 100 in the mines and at sacramento city $12 per hundred & Bacon $20 pr hundred lbs = the timber is now partly made up of scrubby oaks = resembling old apple

trees. made 30 miles = a very hard days work = camped near some canvass groceries = with a spring close by = grass all eat off, = 25th some of our party sold their mules & stopped here to work = we started on & made some 6 or 8 miles when we found off the trail a patch of tolerable grass and a little place where we could dip up water and camped for the Balance of the day = some of the boys left to work on the north fork of the American river. 26th started early some indians came into camp dressed tolerable well,, our way led over hills up & down most of the way, the timber here was scrubby Oak & Pine = the Oaks very much resembles Old Apple trees, & we named the different varieties calling this one a harvest - that a Fall Pippin etc etc & fancied how delicious they would taste,, but our mouths were filled with dust instead & we were riding at the dry season through a parched up country, & our mules almost starving, towards night from a ridge we were crossing, we saw an open strip of country & in a few miles came to a trench ^ & sod fence enclosing occasional girdled Oaks but no other signs of improvement,, soon we saw at some distance from our path the outlines of a house, a welcome sign of civilization, soon came to a wide building used for a store, around were drunken men & Indian boys looking at their faces reflected in the window-glass no doubt a great curiosity to them = milk was here one dollar per quart = meals 8 to 12 shillings = we heard reports of its being very sickly = Dysentery prevailing very extensively & many discouraged & going back home = camped 3 or 4 miles below Johnsons Ranch on Bear river grass tolerable good = 27th started late, went down 10 or 12 miles to Nichols Ranch, & encamped near a slough & near the sacramento river, the slough

seemed abundantly stocked with fish,, they were to be seen (& many seemed of large size) jumping out of the water in every direction especially in the morning 28th Passed the Ranch in the morning, the buildings were old & thatched with the accompanying corral or cattle yard = around the buildings were large scattering Oaks & near by were some Mexicans lassoing cattle, one animals was down with its legs tied, they were riding after another ^ at full speed one had a lasso around the horns = & by riding one on one side & one on the other = they guided the animal towards the one lying down, as they reached the place, the unoccupied lasso was thrown & quick as a thought the beast was thrown by the side of the previously captured animal, with the last lasso around its leg, as the animal struggled the trained horses kept both lassos strained tight, & the animal could not rise, one of the mexicans soon sprang from his horse & tied the feet & the animal ceased tis struggles soon left the shelter of the trees, & struck the open plain or valley, it seemed now dry & barren, but with irrigation would without doubt be productive, passed trains oxen & mules loaded with provisions for the releif of emigrants, still out open the plains, camped on the american river three or four miles north of Sacramento City = grass all eat off = water poor = Hay $6 per 100 lbs = lumber $400 per 1000 ft = & scarce = shingles 40 to $50 per M 28th Went into the city = crossing the American River, when the tide was out & the buildings were mostly cheap frames, covered with canvas the streets were called from the letters of the alphabet from north to south & from the river east were numbered 1, 2, 3

4, 5, etc there were a few tolerable buildings & one or two of sheet iron Rent in very high & also city lots, many have made fortunes in speculating in them one fine Priest, See, & Co commenced with 7 or 8000 and are now reported worth 150,000, made in 8 months, Dr White kindly offered to furnish Mr Philips & myself with $1000 each at simple interest if we wished to speculate in lots. We went and looked the city over, with Dr White = Judge Hastings = & Mr Schoolcraft = but as the rainy season was near at hand & the probability that the city would be flooded in its present situation, we concluded we would try the mines, lots near the river 20 x 70 ft were held at $2000 to $3000 1/4 of a mile back 80 x 150 ft $1000 = the canvass stores seemed to be doing a heavy business, large signs made up for small stores = the streets were crowded with emigrant waggons. Americans & Mexicans/ there were many gambling & eating houses in the city as well as most of the trades represented = we concluded to buy provisions for the mines & pack them on our mules, I left Mr Guns? with Sewell in store. he had joined a Mr Young in the storage & commission business, flour we bought at $8 pr 100 lbs crackers $20 pr 100 lbs butter $4.50 cheese 1.00 pr lb Pork pickeled $19 pr 100 lbs Bacon $45 pr 100 lbs Salmon 50c lb Pickles small bottle 2.50 Vinegar 50c Bottle Rive 10c lb Dried peaches 75c Apples 70c Sugar 18c etc etc we staid a few days to arrange our packs & enquire as to the best "diggins" camped & built our camp fires at the foot of an oak near the slough (which is probably now 1871 in the business party of the city,) saw Mr Frederick? Smith Jr = heard of other friends = while camping near the city the coyotes troubled us very much coming into camp at night & stealing our provisions, some of the boys kept awake & watched for them & shot at them at a few

paces distant but whether any shots took effect we could not tell none were killed outright = one day while hunting for a stray mule I passed within a rod or two of a Prairie wolf who stood & looked at me very impudently. I raised my pistol to fire, but as I had no ammunition, & only one lead, & as I might have need of it before I returned, I let the wolf go, & rode on, image - check mark the birds that are here most plenty are Ravens = Crows =Magpies = Woodpeckers = Ducks = Geese = Cranes etc in the valley above are Elk & antelope & in the hills black tailed Deer & Grizzly bear = an indian came into our camp with fish for sale one fish resembled a sucker another Rock Bass also sun fish & lake herring. 6th left camp for the mines. thought of going to "Reddings Diggings" near the head of the Sacramento = travelled up the east bank of the river  = saw the Prairie on fire & four Elk shot at them with my pistol about fifty or sixty rods distant = but probably without effect soon after saw three Antelope & herds of cattle & horses the cattle were quite wild, travelled about 15 miles = grass poor at our camping ground 7th started & travelled about three miles to Vernon? at the junction of feather river & Sacramento. Fremont is small place just started on the opposite bank = a house that was unfinished in Vernon had already cost $17,000; a house of the same kind could be built & finished in N York state for $1500 = the shingles were not on & the windows not in & most of the siding yet to put on,, travelled about 15 miles = & camped 4 miles beyond Nichols? ranch on Bear river = at this time of year it is only a small stream, our mules crossed the stream in the night & we had some trouble in finding them, we here found very good grass - 8th we crossed the Yuba river a tolerable sized stream, camped again on the banks of the sacramento grass poor - 9th nooned by

a Rancho, near a pool of water = two americans were chasing a steer the horses were well trained & at last a lasso was thrown over its horns & the trained horse wheeled & braced himself for the strain & the steer was brought to a stand, soon after as some dogs commenced barking the steer leaped over them & made a dash to break away but quick as thought the horse braced himself in the opposite direction & this time the steer was thrown with violence stunning the animal & breaking as I supposed his neck from the sound - but it proved to be a horn, the man jumped from his horse drew a long knife from his boot leg & stuck the steer the California cattle are very fat & juicy the meat marbled with the fat & very tender, the drives of horses we saw were round & fat it has been foggy a number of days & about noon it commenced  raining we crossed feather river & camped, under a large oak, the rain came down quite hard & we had wet blankets = some Indians came into camp. I gave one of them some matches & showed him how to make a fire. he seemed very much pleased & showed others of the tribe what they would do = saw during the day indians gathering acorns, 6 or 8 squaws = guided by one indian who carries a long pole probably to whip off the acorns, most of them were nearly naked, with but little beside the fig leaf of adams time, a few had an apology for a blanket their houses. were made by digging a round hole in the ground ten or 12 ft in diameter & from 2 to 4 ft deep, they then put up a frame work of stakes, with poles, laid upon them & then grass upon the poles & then dirt over all to shed water a hole is left in the side as an entrance & when the owner is absent a stick set up before the door , apprises

visitors of the fact, near the houses are cribs made of willow twigs woven together in which they put their acorns. these are thatched with coarse grass to keep out rain & will hold perhaps 15 to 20 bushels? as we passed the Indians came out  & seated themselves on the top of their huts to look at us. when gathering acorns they use (strapped to their backs) baskets made cone shaped the point being down these hold about a bushel of acorns, image - check mark 10th travelled up feather river about 8 miles & as it was 18 miles to the next water we staid till morning, about noon it rained again & kept on all night , it is nearing the rainy season but it seems early yet some of our men used profane language as their clothes became soaked through 11th Travelled 18 miles to Chase's Ranch & camped 12th in the morning had to hunt up our mules that had strayed in the night = on the hunt passed close by a "coyote" or wolf & could easily have shot it also say "California Quail,, they are perhaps some larger than our quails & have a topknot of black feathers on their head = & are excellent eating = travelled 8 miles to Potters Ranch & camped as we have 23 miles to water from here = 13th travelled 23 miles to "Dawsons? Ranch" one of my messmates ^ Mr Bradford from Georgia being some what indisposed to help share in our work = I here seperated & joined Mr Howard & Gazley = 14th made about ten or twelve miles & camped near a waggon party of 8 men all sick with fever & unable to help themselves. we ministered to their wants = & as emigrants passing = all helped them in turn = they did not suffer very much = their teams however had strayed away & it might be doubtful if they were ever found again = 15th travelled about 8 miles to the crossing of the Sacramento = one mule missed the ford & came near going down
