my clothes getting well saturated by the mishap = heard today that it was very sickly at Redding Mines 2/3 were sick & that the mines did not pay as many did not make more than their board 16th we concluded to retrace our steps & try Feather River = & camped again at Lawsons 20 miles = 17 Made 23 miles to Potters Ranch = at our noon camp yesterday saw a man sick with fever & threatened inflamation of the stomach = visited him & prescribed for him & told them what to do for him & urged them to stop with him until he was better,, 16 & 17 were very hot days = passed some dead cattle = heard that on the north or Oregon Route the Indians had been troublesome,, had killed some government Officers & a number of emigrants & stolen cattle & mules & many emigrants were on foot 18th made 8 miles to Chase's 19 made 20 or 25 miles to a spring near "Feather River". Saw some Antelope = & a man sick with inflamation of the Brain from metastisis of Erysipelas, he was in a cloth covered waggon jolting along in the hot sun & the poor man ^ wsa in a raving delirium = I remonstrated with them against such treatment 20th crossed Feather River my mule in crossing stepped in a crevice of the rocky bottom & fell down = wetting me by the operation a Pack mule also stepped in the same crevice & dove head & shoulders under water very much to her disgust. after crossing went up the river on the South bank some 8 or 10 miles to "Bidwells Bar" here were a number of tents one or two brush stores & men at work on a rough rocks bar near the river. we concluded we would stop here & see what the prospects were = 21st started out for the first

time to dig up the "root of all evil" with Picks - Shovels & - Pans = we found some small ravines that would pay from 1/2 oz to 1 oz per day each hand = in the afternoon made the acquaintance of a young man from N.Y. State he in company with two or three others had bought shares in a "Wing Dam" & they were now at work in the bed of the river = he told me that they had five men with one Rocker that took out about $1000,, per day = & had cleared some 8 or $9000,, each, already = I saw the afternoons work some $500,, worth of gold which he was then washing out, the sight was very inspiring = bit I found out afterwards that some places were not quite as rich ^ as others the average now perhaps yeilding from $8 to $16,, per day = our first week we only made some 8,, daily & our crevice? soon gave out,, we now concluded the bed of the river gave the most promise & we each bought a share in a wing dam I made payment with two of my mules = retaining my best one,, but bad luck followed our endeavors,, the fall rains which were not expected so soon set in just as our dam was completed & in one night our dam & Rockers were swept off by a rapidly rising flood & all our hopes dashed & we were left without Rockers = without money & almost without food = I had laid in a greater store than my comrades, but as I could not see them starve I divided as long as my provisions lasted, & soon came to short rations, in the emergency I commenced practice & took provisions in pay = this kept us from starving in the meantime we were out exposed to the soaking rains

which were a continuous outpouring day & night,, Mr Bradford was sick with Typhoid Fever = we made a frame work of poles to keep him off the wet ground, with a bed bottom of our lash ropes, over these we spread pine boughs, & over the whole we made a roof of our blankets,, this kept the storm off the poor fellow partially = but dysentery set in & in spite of all that could be done to releive him he grew rapidly worse & died he was buried in his blankets = Mr Philips & myself concluded we would prospect higher up ^ (on the river) to see if we could find "diggings" with this object I started out to see if I could find any of our mules,, the first day I went alone & travelled so far, that it became dark long before I was prepared for it & ^ while yet a number of miles from our camp,, the prospect seemed fair for my camping alone among the wolves & Grizzlies, as I feared. I could not keep my course in the darkness,  I made out however to find the head of a ravine about four miles from camp & by following this ravine, actually feeling my way down it in the darkness, I made out late at night = to reach camp = Mr Philips the next day went out, & he was less fortunate than I was, he got lost & staid out all night, it rained in the night & he sought refuge under some rocks & as he had no blankets or fire he suffered with cold, & to entertain him the wolves gathered round & gave him a concert, the next day we both went out & found two of our animals, my mule & one of his, next day we packed our mules with provisions & tools etc & started up the river to prospect, it rained all day & out clothes were wet through so when we camped we set fire to a pine covered with resin

& we soon had a pillar of fire by night to dry our clothes by = in the morning we found our mules had left us, we tracked them some miles & found one the other had seperated from him, we spent most of the day in searching for the other but could not find him so we left part of our pack till we should return & went on with one mule, we stopped to noon next day at the "Oregon Bar" worked by oregon men, in the afternoon we travelled along the sides of the mountain up & down the sides of deep ravines that were almost impassable, towards night we struck a faint trail that led towards the river & we concluded to follow it, when we reached the river, two men came out to meet us,, their faces were swarthy as the indian, but as they were both dressed,, we concluded they were Mexicans,, I pointed to them & said "Mexicanas" they shook their heads,, what were they? I pointed to myself & said "American" & the to them = they understood & said "Kanaka", I pointed up the river & enquired "Americans" they shook their heads, then pointed across the mountain towards the "Yuba" we camped near them & by our evening fire we became quite well acquainted, they had a "Kanaka testament & with the help of this, & by signs we could soon make ourselves understood, we found they were about out of provisions & the river too high to work & yet when their scanty supper was ready, they invited us to partake, we compromised the matter & put our provisions with theirs & all eat together, after supper we talked again, we found it was quite difficult for them to get the sound of S or ith, they could count to 15 as we did their letters are pronounced (A "Ah") (E = a) (I - E) (U, "ough") (C "say") (M "Mo") N, "No") W "Way) one wrote quite a fair hand, they gave us to

understand there was a camp of Kanakas a mile or so above, I asked how many,, one looked over his paper where he had put down our pronunciation of the numbers up to 1000 & replied "seventee" I went up after breakfast to their camp & found them packing up to leave as they were out of provisions,, they told us that above there was an impassable "Canon" image - note the caron symbol over the letter 'o'of 'canon' we packed up however & started up the mountain to see if we could not go around it, it was raining after travelling sometime we struck a faint trail, which we tried to follow, but we frequently lost it among the rocks. we passed near indian encampments, but we saw their smokes in time to avoid them, & once we came in sight of their Cribs & piles of acorns, but they did not discover us, we wandered about till after dark & camped in a ravine = to keep our fire out of sight, =  but we came very near not having any fire = our clothes were soaked = most of our matches wet & it rained so we had to build our fire under a blanket = & then we scarcely succeeded in nursing it into life = we were shivering with the cold = the rain being nearly snow,, Mr Philips in searching for some wood in the dark fell into the little stream running through the ravine & made out to soak up a little more water in his clothes than they had previously absorbed, after our fire was strong enough to live in the rain = we fried a little Bacon & warmed some water & soaked some hard bread soft = poor fare = but the prospect was that even this would soon five out. Mr Philips seemed disheartened scarcely wanting any supper, we tried to dry a little our clothes & blankets = we primed anew our pistols & placed them under our heads to keep them dry as

possible, and ready for emergencies, in case our fire had been discovered by prowling savages around us, & then lying down on the wet ground the storm sang us a "Lullaby" in the pines overhead = & we! (well as crying would not do any good) we had to laugh at our forlorn situation = & then went to sleep & slept soundly although "lost in the Sierra's" & unsheltered from the wintery storms & with a dark our look, ahead = the river too high to work = out of money = out of provisions almost,, = roads so nearly impassable that all Provision trains were stopped = & exposed to the storms of winter without shelter of any kind except our blankets, but this was of minor importance now as, we could make a shelter, could we find a place to work, in the morning we ^ found it a little more pleasant but still storming, we travelled north, intending to strike the river at some point opposite, if we could get down to it,, we saw fresh Deer tracks, but did not see any Deer, & also saw some Pigeons, we succeeded in reaching the river & found a bar that looked as though we could work it, but we only found a few scales of gold after trying in different places I here found one scale a perfect heart shape & had this placed upon a ring made from gold I sent home, for dear wife = we spent the day in prospecting, at night, our mule concluded to strike again for better feed & wandered off = In the morning Mr Philips said he would take the trail of his mule & I was to stay with our traps 'till his return

& employ my time in prospecting along the river, I washed with my pan in different places all day with but little success, as the water was so high = & as it grew dark & Mr Philips did not appear, I became somewhat anxious about him = I built a fire in a conspicuous place, hoping if he was lost upon the mountain side, he might see it, & find his way in, I then retired to a safe distance, & hid myself among the rocks to prevent any prowling savages from taking unfair advantage of my peculiar situation, ^ in the night the storm broke in again & so passed the second day & second night, & into the afternoon of the third day, & I had concluded something more than common had happened to Mr Philips,, & had packed up a few of the traps to take upon my back, & had hidden the balance,, & was just ready for a start as Mr Philips came in sight without the stray mule, he had tracked it a number of miles, & finally lost the trail, he kept up the search,, & towards night of the second day, struck a path that he followed until he saw the prints of naked feet = clearly this led to an indian camp, so he left the trail & struck across the ravine. he had reached the other side, when a savage yell arose behind him, he drew his pistol & turned to face his foes, but not a savage appeared in view, he then started on, when the yell was repeated, & he again stopped & turned, & then resumed his

Journey without farther molestation, or sight of a "Red Skin" why they concluded not to put in an appearance he was at a loss to know, after a hasty meal we packed our traps upon our backs, & took our way along the sides of the mountain, down the river, until we came to the outskirts of civilization, a "Miners Cabin." here we left part of ^ our load (which we afterwards returned for) & with the balance on our backs made our way back over the mountains,, our mishaps did not discourage us, we found friends kind enough to leave us provisions & finding three stray mules belonging to our Party one started with them to pack in provisions & freight hoping to make this pay, the roads however (after the first soaking) soon became more settled & then waggons again made their appearance, & packing was not so profitable,, we now heard of a bar on the middle fork of the Feather river,, which I ^ had almost reached on a previous prospecting tour, (when Mr Bradford was taken sick) we packed up our tools & commenced work the first days work turning out $106,, or over six & 1/2 oz's for three of us $35 33 1/3 each) the days works varied from this down to 1/2 oz to the hand, it rained full 1/2 the time, we worked from Daylight 'till dark if it did not storm too hard to stopping only for meals,, & to pan out the gold in the bottom of the rocker, & to pack up provisions = we had constructed a shelter of logs & Blankets, with pine boughs

page 108 for a bed - built our fire outside against some rocks the rain often interfered with our cooking,, but we soon got used to it, & made no complaints, if our PanCake batter happened to get mixed a little too thin or our bread an extra wetting, or if we had a little too much gravy for the meat & yet after doing all our own work, it cost us about $5,, each, daily for board at our hotel, for we paid in gold dust about 15c pr lb for beef fattened on the plains, 1 00 to 1,25 for Pork & Flour pr lb 1 00 pr lb for Potatoes (butter none to be had) Pickles, 3,, pr Qt etc etc
